name: Lagos
fun_fact: Fun fact: Lagos is Africa's largest city with over 21 million people and is projected to become the world's largest city by 2100. It was built on a collection of islands and lagoons, and its name comes from the Portuguese word for 'lakes' - they arrived in the 15th century!

hero_dishes.name: Jollof Rice
hero_dishes.description: Tomato-based rice cooked with peppers, onions, and spices - West Africa's most beloved dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: The 'Jollof Wars' between Nigeria and Ghana are legendary - Nigerians insist theirs is superior (smoky party-style)
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Yellow Chilli, Nkoyo, any 'owambe' party, street vendors

hero_dishes.name: Suya
hero_dishes.description: Spiced grilled meat skewers coated in ground peanut 'yaji' spice mix
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originally from northern Nigeria's Hausa people - now Lagos's essential late-night street food
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Suya spots everywhere, especially Yaba, Allen Avenue, Victoria Island at night

hero_dishes.name: Egusi Soup
hero_dishes.description: Rich soup made with ground melon seeds, leafy vegetables, and meat or fish, eaten with pounded yam
hero_dishes.origin_story: A pan-Nigerian staple - the melon seeds give it a distinctive thick, nutty texture
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Terra Kulture, Buka restaurants, home cooking

hero_dishes.name: Puff Puff
hero_dishes.description: Deep-fried dough balls, slightly sweet and fluffy - Nigeria's donut
hero_dishes.origin_story: West African street food essential - every street vendor has their recipe
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors everywhere, especially mornings and evenings

signature_drinks.name: Chapman
signature_drinks.description: Nigerian cocktail with Fanta, Sprite, grenadine, and Angostura bitters
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At parties and restaurants - the signature Nigerian soft cocktail

signature_drinks.name: Palm Wine
signature_drinks.description: Fresh sap from palm trees, milky and naturally fermented
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At palm wine joints and local bars - fresh is sweet, older is stronger

food_culture_notes: Buka restaurants serve authentic home-style Nigerian food at low prices
Owambe parties (celebrations) are where to taste the best Jollof
'Mama Put' refers to women selling home-cooked food on the street
Victoria Island and Ikoyi have upscale dining; mainland has authentic spots
